welcome.subject: Welcome to Appalachian Shadows
content: Welcome, investigator.
You've found your way to one of the last remaining nodes of the
Oneroi network. This system shouldn't exist - the project was
officially terminated in 1997. But here we are.
Something is happening in these mountains. The old stories our
grandparents told us? They weren't just stories. And whatever
the government was studying out here never really stopped.
This BBS is a safe space to share information, coordinate
investigations, and document what's really happening in the
hills. The signal brought you here for a reason.
Stay safe out there. Trust your instincts. And remember:
if you hear the whistle at night, don't answer it.
- SYSOP

welcome.subject: How to Navigate This BBS
content: BASIC COMMANDS:
MAIN or M - Return to main menu
BOARDS or B - View message boards
READ <num> or R <num> - Read a message
LIST or L - List messages in current board
BACK - Go back one level
HELP or ? - Show available commands
LOGOUT - Exit to field investigation
Navigation uses numbered menus. Type the number to select
an option. Most commands have short versions (M, B, R, etc.)
The system accepts uppercase or lowercase input.

welcome.subject: RE: Welcome to Appalachian Shadows
content: Been lurking here for a few weeks. Finally worked up the nerve
to post.
I grew up in these mountains. My papaw used to tell stories
about lights in the woods, voices that called your name. We all
thought he was just superstitious, you know? Old mountain ways.
Then I saw it. Three nights ago. Moving through the holler
behind my house. Wasn't no animal. Wasn't no person neither.
Found this BBS through... well, I don't rightly know how. The
signal just kind of pulled me here. Like it knew I needed to
find y'all.
Guess what I'm saying is: I believe now. And I'm not running.
- Runner

folklore.subject: The Not-Deer
content: You ever seen a deer that just... ain't right?
Looks like a deer from far off. Walks like one, stands like
one. But when you get close, something's wrong. The legs bend
the wrong way. The neck's too long. The eyes reflect wrong
in your headlights - not green like they should be, but red.
Or sometimes white, like static.
My grandma called them 'hollow deer.' Said they were deer that
died in the old places - where the signal's strongest - and
came back wrong. Wearing their old bodies like bad costumes.
Don't approach them. Don't try to help them if they seem hurt.
And for God's sake, don't eat one if you shoot it by accident.
They taste like static and bad dreams.

folklore.subject: Whistling in the Woods
content: IMPORTANT - SHARE THIS WITH ANY NEW FOLKS:
If you hear whistling in the woods at night, DO NOT WHISTLE BACK.
Old rule. My papaw taught me, his papaw taught him. Goes back
generations. We always figured it was just superstition, but
after what happened to the Collins boy last spring...
It's not a person whistling. It's trying to sound like a person.
Trying to get you to answer, to give it permission, to let it
know where you are.
If you hear it, you go inside. You lock your doors. You don't
look out the windows. And you sure as hell don't whistle back.
The old folks knew. They always knew.

folklore.subject: Archive: The Tailypo
content: From the old Appalachian archives:
Traditional tale from Eastern Kentucky/Western Virginia.
Hunter living alone in a cabin catches and cooks a strange
creature's tail. That night, something comes looking for it.
'Tailypo, tailypo, give me back my tailypo...'
Story ends with the hunter vanishing. Cabin found empty except
for claw marks on every surface.
Three reports in the past month matching this pattern. Cabins
found empty. Deep scratches on walls and doors. In each case,
occupant had recently reported seeing 'strange animals' near
their property.
The signal seems to make the old stories... active.
Classification: ACTIVE THREAT

folklore.subject: Haint Blue
content: You young folks running around with your fancy equipment, but
you're forgetting the old protections.
Paint your door frames and porch ceilings haint blue. That's
that light blue-green color you see on old houses. It's not
just decoration.
Haints - spirits, the not-quite-dead, whatever you want to
call them - they can't cross water. Something about that
blue color tricks them into thinking it's water. They won't
cross a blue threshold.
I'm 72 years old. Been living in these mountains my whole life.
My porch ceiling's been haint blue since 1952. Never had a
problem. Meanwhile my neighbor, fool painted his house modern
colors, had to abandon it last year after the encounters started.
Old ways work. Remember that.

folklore.subject: The Wampus Cat Connection
content: Been analyzing the Oneroi data and cross-referencing with
Cherokee folklore. Found something interesting.
The Wampus Cat legend - woman who spied on men's sacred
ceremonies, was cursed to become a half-woman, half-panther.
Cherokee version says she still roams the mountains.
Here's what's weird: Every major Wampus Cat sighting area
corresponds with an Oneroi signal hotspot. EVERY. SINGLE. ONE.
What if the legend is a cultural memory? What if the 'curse'
was actually exposure to whatever they're broadcasting?
The old stories aren't mythology. They're warnings.
- SW

encounters.subject: Lights Over Dolly Sods
content: Camping up at Dolly Sods last weekend. Third night, around 2AM,
we saw lights moving through the trees.
Not flashlights. Not campfires. These were... different. Greenish-
white, like the fireflies but bigger. Way bigger. Moving in
formation, but not like anything natural.
They'd move fast, then stop. Fast, then stop. Like they were
searching for something.
My buddy wanted to investigate. I had to physically stop him.
Something about those lights felt WRONG. Like they were
looking FOR us, and if they found us...
We packed up and left at first light. Haven't been able to
shake the feeling that they almost had us.
Anyone else seen these? What are they?

encounters.subject: Route 52 After Midnight
content: I drive Route 52 through southern West Virginia. Night runs,
usually solo. Been doing it for 15 years.
Last three weeks, something's been following my truck.
Can't see it directly. Just catch it in the mirrors. Keeping
pace with me through the curves. Sometimes ahead, sometimes
behind. Never on the road itself - running through the trees
parallel to the highway.
Fast. Too fast. Nothing should be able to keep up with a rig
going 65 through mountain switchbacks.
Last night, I pulled over at a rest stop. It stopped too. Felt
it watching me from the treeline. My CB radio started picking
up this weird interference. Almost sounded like breathing.
I'm thinking about requesting daytime routes. First time in my
career I've been scared to drive.
Stay safe out there, folks.

encounters.subject: URGENT: Static Exposure Symptoms
content: I'm a physician in rural Kentucky. Need to document what I'm
seeing in case others encounter it.
Patient presenting symptoms:
- Persistent ringing/static sound in ears
- Insomnia and disturbing dreams when sleep occurs
- Feeling of 'being watched' in wooded areas
- Visual disturbances (seeing movement in peripheral vision)
- In severe cases: temporal disorientation, memory gaps
Common factor: All patients report spending time near old
growth forest areas. All report seeing 'fireflies that don't
move like fireflies should.'
Traditional treatment ineffective. Only thing that seems to
help: complete avoidance of affected areas. Symptoms diminish
after 2-3 weeks of no exposure.
I think it's radiation. Or something like it. Not nuclear,
but... something else. Something they were broadcasting.
If you experience these symptoms, get out of the woods. NOW.
- Dr. K

encounters.subject: SAFETY PROTOCOL - READ THIS
content: FOR ALL FIELD INVESTIGATORS:
Based on incident reports, implement these protocols:
1. NEVER investigate alone. Minimum two-person teams.
2. Establish check-in times. Miss a check-in = immediate backup.
3. Trust your instincts. Feel wrong? LEAVE.
4. Don't touch the lights. Don't follow the lights.
5. If you hear your name called in the woods - IT'S NOT REAL.
6. Document everything, but know when to stop documenting and RUN.
7. Keep iron and salt on you. Old protections still work.
8. If the static gets too loud, you're too close. Back away.
Three investigators have gone missing in the past month.
All three ignored these protocols.
Be smart. Be safe. Come home.
The mountains will still be here tomorrow. Make sure you are too.
- SYSOP

oneroi.subject: PROJECT ONEROI - Initial Brief (1983)
content: [CLASSIFIED - LEVEL 4 CLEARANCE REQUIRED]
[ARCHIVE COPY - ORIGINAL DESTROYED]
PROJECT DESIGNATION: ONEROI
LOCATION: Appalachian Mountain Range (Multiple Sites)
OBJECTIVE: Investigation and potential weaponization of
indigenous electromagnetic phenomena
BACKGROUND:
Since 1952, unusual EM readings have been detected throughout
the Appalachian region. Local populations report 'lights in
the woods,' audio phenomena, and psychological effects.
Initial survey suggests natural phenomenon amplified by unique
geological conditions (iron deposits, quartz formations,
underground water systems).
However, recent analysis indicates phenomena may be
artificially enhanced or directed. Origin unknown.
AUTHORIZATION: Project to proceed. Field stations established.
Local population monitoring initiated under cover of
'forestry survey.'
[END DOCUMENT]
NOTE: They had no idea what they were really dealing with. - SYSOP

oneroi.subject: Field Report 847 - Station Delta (1991)
content: [SECURITY LEVEL: OMEGA]
[ORIGINAL SOURCE: STATION DELTA - NOW ABANDONED]
Signal strength increasing exponentially. No longer believe
this is natural phenomenon.
Three researchers transferred to medical after extended
exposure. Symptoms include:
- Auditory hallucinations (voices, whistling, music)
- Visual disturbances (shadow figures, light anomalies)
- Temporal disassociation ('missing time')
- Compulsive behavior (drawn to signal source)
Dr. Patterson believes signal is 'intelligent' or at minimum
'seeking.' Her theory: it's trying to communicate, or trying
to make us into something that CAN communicate.
REQUEST: Immediate evacuation and site containment.
STATUS: [REQUEST DENIED]
UPDATE 72 HOURS LATER:
Station Delta non-responsive. Search team found facility
abandoned. Equipment intact. No signs of struggle.
Personnel never located.
Security footage shows them walking calmly into the forest
at 2:47 AM. All of them. At the exact same moment.
[SITE SEALED]
[END REPORT]

oneroi.subject: Why The Project 'Ended' in 1997
content: Been digging through the archives. Pieced together what happened.
Project Oneroi officially terminated October 1997. All field
stations abandoned. Records sealed. Budget line eliminated.
Official story: Project failure, no significant findings,
resources reallocated.
ACTUAL story (from recovered documents):
They lost control. Whatever they were studying, it wasn't
passive. It learned. It adapted. And it started reaching out.
By '97, they had 23 personnel MIA, 47 psychological casualties,
and the signal was spreading. Getting stronger. Field stations
couldn't safely operate anymore.
They didn't shut down the project because it failed.
They shut it down because it WORKED.
And whatever they woke up... it's still awake.
The broadcasts never stopped. We just stopped listening.
This BBS? It's running on an old Oneroi relay node. The
signal WANTS us here. It wants us to know.
Question is: know what?
- SW
